repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Trade and Transport
            Facilitation in South East Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Trade and Transport Facilitation in
            South East Europe Project in Macedonia had a satisfactory
            outcome, is likely to be sustainable, and has a substantial
            development impact. The performances of the Borrower and the
            Bank are rated satisfactory. Project and program-related
            lessons pertained to interagency cooperation at border cross
            points, replication of procedures at pilot sites, customs
            control culture, support for the trade and transport
            facilitation in South East Europe website, procedures on
            border stations, multifunctional border inspection
            facilities, comprehensive solutions for border/clearance
            delays, high level government support, cumbersome visa
            procedures and requirements for professional drivers that
            slow down road freight transport, the bank's focus in
            the future programs, a holistic corridor approach at the
            regional level, policy dialogue, flexibility in project
            design,  synchronization of proposed activities at the
            regional level, the contribution of the United States as a
            parallel financier, avoiding overlaps with the European
            Union's integrated border management,  there must be a
            simple organizing principle to help
            implementation/supervision in multi-country operations, and
            using the same project team across countries in
            multi-country operations.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Trade and Transport
            Facilitation in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Trade and Transport Facilitation in
            Southeast Europe Project aims to strengthen and modernize
            the customs administrations and other border control
            agencies in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia,
            Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, and
            Romania. In this project FYR Macedonia seeks two development
            objectives: to reduce non-tariff costs to trade and
            transport; and to prevent smuggling and corruption at border
            crossings. There are five project components. The first
            improves customs procedures, assists streamline operations
            at three border posts and one inland terminal on a pilot
            basis; provides customs training in new procedures, and
            trains for agency awareness and cooperation; and
            restructures the customs administration. The second
            component provides technical assistance and advisory
            services to trade and international transport participants
            through the European chamber; improves communication between
            border control agencies and trading community by using a
            virtual forum; and supplies equipment. The third component
            improves information system, provides personnel training,
            and stimulates regional and inter-agency cooperation. The
            fourth component improves border crossing facilities. The
            fifth component includes the services to support program implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Trade and Transport
            Facilitation in Southeast Europe - environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The review of the project components for
            the Trade and Transportation Facilitation in Southeast
            Europe Project for Macedonia indicated that the project is
            unlikely to have significant adverse environmental impacts
            and is accordingly confirmed as a category B project. To
            prevent, minimize, or mitigate site specific negative
            impacts, however, this environmental management plan (EMP)
            and a set of mitigation measures have been prepared. The
            major concerns about possible negative site specific impacts
            associated with border crossings relate to 1) emissions from
            vehicles waiting for custom clearances; 2) drainage of
            disinfectants and spills of oils and fuel; 3) waste disposal
            and loose garbage; and 4) site disruptions caused by
            upgrades or relocations of utilities or such infrastructure
            as buildings, parking/waiting areas, and access roads.
            Specific actions to minimize any potentially negative impact
            and promote institutional development include liaising with
            environmental authorities and reviewing and monitoring EMP
            compliance; staff training and sensitization at each border
            crossing; certifying acceptable practices and impact
            minimization, especially storing and properly using
            disinfecting materials and chemicals, and hazardous
            materials and garbage; harmonizing regulatory requirements
            with European Union and international standards; and
            incorporating environmental plans in consultant contracts
            and project design.
